sp.l: I bring youDio. ibid. letters, and a health from Caesar.

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: Sir both come wel.

sp.speaker: MAC
sp.l: (And heare you, with your note
Which are the eminent Men, and most of Action.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: That shall be done you too).

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: Most worthy Laco,
Caesar salutes you. (Consull! death, and furies!
Gone now?) the Argument will please you, Sir.
(Hough! Regulus? The anger of the Gods
Follow your diligent legges, and ouer take 'hem,
In likenesse of the Goute.) ô, good my Lord,
We lackt you present; I would pray you send
Another to Fulcinius Trio, straight,
To tell him, you will come, and speake with him:
(The matter wee'le deuise) to stay him, there,
While I, with Laco, do suruay the watch.
What are your strengths, Gracinus?

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: De praefecto vigilū vid. Ros. Ant. Rom. lib. 7. et Dio. Rom. Hist. lib. 55. seauen Cohorts.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: You see, what Caesar writes: and (— gone againe?
H'has sure a veine of Mercurie in his feete)
Knew you, what store of the Praetorian Souldiers
Seianus holds, about him for his guard?

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: I cannot the iust number: But, I thinke,
Three Centuries.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: Three? good.

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: At most, not foure.

sp.speaker: MAC,
sp.l: And who be those Centurions?

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: That the Consul
Can best deliuer you.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: (When h'is away,
Spight, on his nimble industry.) Gracinus,
You find what place you hold, there, in the Trust
Of royall Caesar?

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: I, and I am—

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: Sir,
The Honors, there propos'd, are but beginnings
Of his great fauours.

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: They are more—

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: I heard him
When he did study, what to adde—

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: My life,
And all I hold—

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: You were his owne first choise;
Which doth confirme as much, as you can speake:
And will (if we succeed) make more—Your guardes
Are seauen Cohorts, you say?

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: Dio. Hist. Rom. lib. 58. pag. 718. Those we must
Hold still in readines, and vndischarg'd.

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: I vnderstand so much. But how it can—

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: Be done without suspition, you'll obiect?

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: The keeping of the Watch in armes,
When morning comes.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: The Senate shall be met, and set
So early, in the Temple, as all marke
Of that will be auoided.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: If we need,
We haue commission, Vid. Tac. Ann. lib. 6. pag. 107. Et Suet. Tib. cap. 65 to possesse the Pallace;
Enlarge Prince Drusus, and make him our Chiefe:

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: (That Secret would haue burn't his reuerend mouth,
Had he not spit it out, now:) By the Gods,
You carrie things too—Let me borrow' a man,
Or two, to beare these— That of freeing Drusus,
Caesar proiected as the last, and vtmost;
Not else to be remembred.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: Here are seruants.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: These to Arruntius, These to Lepidus,
This beare to Cotta, This to Latiaris.
If they demaund you'of me, say, I haue tâne
Fresh horse, and am departed. You (my Lord)
To your Colleague; and be you sure, to hold him
With long narration, of the new fresh fauours,
Meant to Seianus, his great Patron; I
With trusted Laco, here, are for the guards:
Then, to diuide. "For, Night hath many eyes,
"Whereof, though most do sleepe, yet some are Spies.

div.stage: Hi omnibus sacrificijs interesse solebant. Ros. Ant. Rom. lib. 3. Stuch. de Sac. pag. 72. TVBICINES. TIBICINES. PRAECONES. Ex ijs, qui Flamines Curiales dicerentur. vid. Lil. Greg. Gyr. Synt. 17. & Onup. Pāuin. Rep. Rom. Comment. 2.FLAMEN. MINISTRI. SEIANVS. TERENTIVS. SATRIVS. &c.

sp.speaker: PRAE.
sp.l: Moris antiqui erat, praecones praecedere, & sacris arcere profanos. Cons. Briss. Ros. Stuch. Lil. Gyt. &c.BE ALL PROFANE FAR HENCE; Fly, fly far of:
Be absent far; FAR HENCE BE ALL PROFANE.

sp.speaker: TVB. TIB.
sp.l: These sound,Obseruatum antiquis inuenimus, vt qui rem diuinam facturus esset, lautus, ac mundus accederet, & ad suas leuandas culpas, se inprimis reum dicere solitum, & noxae penituisse. Lil. Gyr. Synt. 17. while the Flamen washeth.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: We haue bene faulty, but repent vs now;
And bringJn sacris puras manus, puras vestes, pura vasa, &c. Antiqui desiderabant. vt ex Virg. Plant. Tibul. Oui. &c. pluribus locis constat. pure Hands, pure Vestments, and pure Minds:

sp.speaker: MIN
sp.l: And pure Offrings.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: BestowAlius ritus, sertis aras coronare, & verbenas imponere. your Ghyrlonds: and (with reuerence) place
The Veruin on the Altar.

sp.speaker: PRAE.
sp.l: Huiusmodi vocibus silentium imperatum fuisse constat. Vid. Sen. in lib. de beata vita. Seru. & Don. ad cum versum. lib. 5. AEneid. Ore fauete omnes, & cingite tempora ramis.FAVOR YOVR TONGVES.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: His solemnibus praefationibus in sacris vtebantur. Great mother FORTVNE, Queene of humane state,

l.hi: Rectresse of Action, Arbitresse of Fate,
To whom all sway, all power, all empire bowes,
Be present, and propitious to our vowes.

sp.speaker: PRAE.
sp.l: Quibu • , in clausu, populus vel caetus à praeconibus fauere inbebatur. id est bona verba fari. Talis enim altera huius formulae interpretatio apud Briss. lib. 1. extat. Oui. lib. 1. Fast. Linguis animis{que} fanete. Et Metam. lib. 15.—piumque AEneadae praestant & mente, & voce fauorem.FAVOR IT WITH YOVR TONGVES.

sp.speaker: MIN.

p.hi: Be present, and propitious to our vowes.

sp.p: While they sound againe, the Flamen Ʋocabatur hic Ritus Libatio. lege. Rosin. Ant. lib. 3. Bar. Brissō. de form. lib. 1. Stn chium. de Sacrif. Et Lil. Synt 17. takes of the Honey, with his finger, and tasts; then ministers to all the rest: so of theJn sacris Fortunae lacte, non vino libabant. ijsdem Test. Talia sacrificia 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , & 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dictae. Hoc est sobria, & vino carentia. Milke, in an earthen vessell, he deales about; which done he sprinkleth, vpon the Altar, Milke; then imposeth the Honey; and kindleth his Gummes, and after censing about the Altar, placeth his Censer thereon, into which theyHoc reddere erat, & litare, id est propitiare, & votum impetrare: secundum Nonium Marcellum. Litare etiam Mac. lib. 3. cap. 5. explicat, sacrificio facto placare numen. In quo sens. leg. apud Plaut. Suet. Senec. &c. put seuerall branches of Poppy, and the musique ceasing, say all,Solennis formula, in donis cuiuis numini offerrendis. Accept our Offring, and be pleas'd great Goddesse.

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: See, see, the Image stirres.

sp.speaker: SAT.
sp.l: And turnes away.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.l: Fortune Leg. Dio. Rom. Hist. lib. 58. pag. 717. de hoc sacrificio. auerts her face.

sp.speaker: FLA
sp.l: Auert you Gods
The prodigie. Still! still! Some pious Rite
We haue neglected. Yet! Heau'n, be appeas'd.
And be all tokens false, or void, that speake
Thy present wrath.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Be thou dumbe, scrupu'lous Priest:
And gather vp thy selfe, with these thy wares,
Which I, in spight of thy blind Mistresse, or
Thy iugling mystery, Religion, throw
Thus, scorned on the earth. Nay, hold thy looke
Auerted, till I woe thee turne againe;
And thou shalt stand, to all posterity,
Th'eternall game, and laughter, with thy neck
Writh'd to thy taile, like a ridiculous Cat:
Auoid these fumes, these superstitious Lights,
And all these coos'ning Ceremonies; You.
Your pure, and spiced conscience. I, the Slaue,
And Mocke of Fooles, (Scorne on my worthy head,)
That haue beneTac. Ann. lib. 4. pa. 96. titled, and ador'd a God,
Yea,Dio. lib. 58. pag. 716 717. sacrific'd vnto, my selfe, in Rome,
No lesse then Ioue: and I be brought, to doe
A peeuish Giglot rites? Perhaps, the thought,
And shame of that made Fortune turne her face,
Knowing her selfe the lesser Deity,
And but my Seruant: bashfull Queene, if so,
Seianus thanks thy modesty. Who's that?

div.stage: POMPONIVS.De Minutio. vid. Tac. Ann. lib. 6. MINVTIVS. &c.

sp.speaker: POM.
sp.l: His Fortune suffers, till he heares my newes:
I'haue wayted here too long. Macro, my Lord—

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Speake lower, & withdraw.

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: Are these things true?

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.l: Thousands are gazing at it, in the streetes.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: Minutius tells vs here, my Lord,
That, a new Head being set vpon your Statue.
A Dio. Hist. Rom. lib. 58. pag. 717. Rope is since found wreath'd about it; And,
But now,Vid. Sen. Nat. Quaest. lib. 1. cap. 1. a fiery Meteor, in the forme
Of a great ball, was seene to roule along
The troubled ayre, where yet it hangs, vnperfect,
The'amazing wonder of the Multitude.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: No more. That Macro's come, is more then all.

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: Is Macro come?

sp.speaker: POM.
sp.l: I saw him.

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: Where? with whom?

sp.speaker: POM.
sp.l: With Regulus.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Terentius,—

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Dio. pag. 718.Send for the Tribunes, we will straight haue vp
More of the Souldiers, for our guard. Minutius,
Wee pray you goe for Cotta, Latiaris,
Trio the Consull, or what Senatours
You know are sure, and ours. You, my good Natta,
For Laco, Prouost of the watch. Now, Satrius,
The Time of proofe comes on. Arme all our seruants,
And without tumult. You Pomponius,
Hold some good Correspondence, with the Consul,
Attempt him, noble Friend. These things beginne
To looke like dangers, now, worthy my Fates.
Fortune, I see thy worst: "Let doubtfull states,
"And things vncertaine hang vpon thy will:
"Me surest Death shall render certaine still.
Yet, why is, now, my thought turn'd toward death,
Whom Fates haue let goe on, so farre, in breath,
Vncheck'd, or vnreproou'd? I,Vid. Tac. Ann. lib. 1. pag. 23. that did helpe
To fell the lofty Cedar of the world,
Germanicus; that, at one stroake, Ann. lib. 4. pag. 74. 75. Et Dio. lib. 57. pag. 709. cut downe
Drusus, that vpright Elme; wither'd his Vine;

LaidTac. Lib. 4 pag. 79. Silius, andEt pag. 94.—Dion. Rom. Hist. lib. 58.712.
Sabinus, two strong Oakes,
Flat on the earth; besides those other shrubs,

De Cremutio Cor. vid. Dio. Rom. Hist. lib. 57. pag. 710. Tacit. Ann. lib. 4. pa. 83.
Cordus, and De Sofia. Tac. Annal. lib. 4. pa. 94. Sosiae,
De Clau. & Furnio. quaere Tac. lib. 4. pa. 89. Claudia Pulchra,
And since, haue set my Axe so strong, and deepe,
Into the roote of spreading De Agr. Ner. & Dru. leg. Suet. Tib. cap. 53. 54. Agrippine,
Lopt off, and scatterd her proud branches, Nero,
Drusus; and De Caio. Cons. Dio. lib. 58. pag. 717. Caius too, although replanted:
If you will, Destinies, that, after all,
I faint, now, êre I touch my period;
You are but cruell: and I already 'haue done
Things great inough. All Rome, hath bene my Slaue;
The Senate sate an idle Looker on,
And Witnesse of my power; when I haue blush'd,
More, to command, then it to suffer: All
The Fathers haue sate ready, and prepar'd,
To giue me Empire, Temples, or their Throates,
When I would aske 'hem; And, what crownes the top,
Rome, Senate, People, all the World haue seene
Ioue, but my aequall; Caesar, but my Second.
"Tis then your malice, Fates, who (but your owne)
"Enuye, and feare t'haue any power long knowne.

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: Stay here: I'le giue his Lordship, you are come.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.l: Marcus Terentius, pray you tell my Lord,
Here's Cotta, and Latiaris.

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: My Letter is the very same with yours;
Onely requires me to be present there,
And giue my voice, to strengthen his dissigne:

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: Names he not what it is?

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: No, nor to you.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: Tis strange, and singular doubtfull!

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: So it is!
It may bee all is left to Lord Seianus.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.l: Gentlemen, where's my Lord?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Wee waite him here.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: The Prouost Laco? what's the newes?

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: My Lord—

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Now, My right deare, noble, and trusted Friends;
How much I am a Captiue to your kindnesse!
Most worthy Cotta, Latiaris, Laco,
Your valiant hand; and Gentlemen, your Loues.
I wish I could deuide my selfe vnto you;
Or that it lay, within our narrow powers,
To satisfie for so enlarged bounty.
Gracinus, we must pray you hold your Guards
Vnquit, when Morning comes. Saw you the Consull?

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.l: Trio will presently be here my Lord;

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l:
They are but Vid. Dio.
•• b. 58. pag. 718. giuing order for the Edict,
To warne the Senate.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: How the Senate?

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: Yes.
This morning, in Apollo's Temple.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: We
Are charg'd, by Letter, to be there my Lord.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: By Letter? pray you lett's see.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: Knows not his Lordsh?

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: It seemes so.

sp.speaker: SE.
sp.l: A Senate warn'd? without my knowledge?
And on this sodaine? Senators by Letters
Required to be there? Who brought these?

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Dio. ibid. Mine enemy. And when?

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: This midnight.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Time,
With eu'ry other circumstance, doth giue
It hath some streine of Engin in't. How now?

sp.speaker: SAT.
sp.l: My Lord, Sertorius Macro is without,Dio. ibid.
Alone, and prayes t'haue priuate conference
In businesse, of high nature, with your Lordship,
He say's to mee; and which reguards you much.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Let him come here.

sp.speaker: SAT.
sp.l: better, my Lord, withdraw,
You will betray what store, and strength of friends
Are now about you; which he comes to spie.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Is he not arm'd?

sp.speaker: SAT.
sp.l: Wee'll search him.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: No, but take,
And lead him to some roome, where you, conceald,
May keepe a guard vpon vs. Noble Laco,
You are our trust: And, till our • wne Cohorts
Can be brought vp, your Strengths must be our Guard,
Now good Minutius, honour'd Latiaris,
Most worthy, and my most vnwearied Friends;
I returne instantly.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: Most worthy Lord!

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: His Lordship is turn'd instant kind, me thinks,
I'haue not obseru'd it in him, heretofore.

sp.speaker: TRI. 1.
sp.l: Tis true, and it becomes him nobly.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.l: I
Am rap't withall.

sp.speaker: TRI. 2.
sp.l: By Mars, he has my liues,
(Were they a million) for this onely grace.

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: I, and to name a man?

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: As he did me!

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.l: And me!

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: Who would not spend his Life & Fortunes,
To purchase but the looke of such a Lord?

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: He, that would nor be Lords foole, nor the Worlds.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Macro! most welcome, as most coueted friend, Dio. Hist. Rom. lib. 58. pag. 718.
Let me enioy my longings. When arriu'd you?

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: About the Merid ies noctis. Varr. Marcipor. vid. Non. Mar. cap. 6. noone of Night.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Satrius, giue leaue.

sp.speaker: MAC
sp.l: I haue bene since I came, with both the Consul's,
On a particular dissigne from Caesar.

sp.speaker: SEI,
sp.l: How fares it with our great, and royall Master?

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: Right plentifully well; As, with a Prince,
Dio. ibid. That still holds out the great proportion
Of his large fauours, where his iudgement hath
Made once diuine election: like the God,
That wants not, nor is wearied to bestow
Where merit meetes his bounty, as it doth
In you, already the most happy, and ere
The sunne shall climbe the South, most high Seianus.
Let not my Lord be'amus'd. For to this end
Was I by Caesar sent for, to the Isle,
Which speciall caution to conceale my iourney;
And, thence, had my dispatch as priuately
Dio. ibid. Againe to Rome; charg'd to come here by night;
And, onely to the Consuls, make narration
Of his great purpose: that the benefit
Might come more full, and striking, by how much
It was lesse loo'kd for, or aspir'd by you;
Or least informed to the common Thought.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: What may this be? Part of my selfe, deare Macro,
If good, speake out: and share with your Seianus.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: If bad, I should for euer loath my selfe
To be the messenger to so good a Lord.
I doe exceed m'Instructions, to acquaint
Your Lordship with thus much; but 'tis my venture
On your retentiue wisdome: and, because
Dio. ibid. I would no iealous scruple should molest
Or rack your peace of thought. For I assure
My noble Lord, no Senator yet knowes
The businesse meant: though All, by seuerall Letters,
Are warned to be there, and giue their voyces,
Onely to adde vnto the state, and grace
Of what is purpos'd.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: You take pleasure, Macro,
Like a coy Wench, in torturing your Louer.
What can be worth this suffering?

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: That which followes,
Dio. ibid. The Vid. Suet. de oppress. Scian. Tib. cap. 65. Tribuniciall Dignity, and Power:
Both which Seianus is to haue this day
Conferd vpon him, and by publique Senate.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Fortune, be mine againe; Thou' hast satisfied
For thy suspected loyalty.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: My Lord,
I haue no longer time, the day approacheth,
And I must back to Caesar.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: wher's Caligula?

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: That I forgot to tel your Lordship. Why,
He lingers yonder, about Capreae,
Disgrac'd; Tiberius hath not seene him yet:
He needes would thrust himselfe to goe with me,
Against my wish, or will, but I haue quitted
His forward trouble, with as tardy note
As my Neglect, or Silence could bestow.
Your Lordship cannot now command me ought,
Because, I take no knowledge that I sawe you,
But I shall boast to liue to serue your Lordship
And so take leaue.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Honest, and worthy Macro,
Your Loue, and Friendship. Who's there? Satrius,
Attend my honourable friend forth. O!
How vaine, and vile a passion is this Feare?
What base, vncomly things it makes men doe?
Suspect their noblest friends, (as I did this)
Flatter poore enemies, intreat their seruants,
Stoupe, court, and catch at the beneuolence
Of Creatures, vnto whom (within this howre)
I would not haue vouchsaf'd a quarter-looke,
Or peice of face? By you, that Fooles call Gods,
Hang all the Skie with your prodigious Signes,
Fill earth with Monsters, drop the Scorpion, downe,
Out of the Zodiack, or the fiercer Lion,
Shake off the loos'ned Globe from her long henge,
Roule all the World in darkenesse, and let loose
Th'inraged Winds to turne vp Groues and Townes;
When I do feare againe, let me be strooke
With forked fire, and vnpitied die:
"Who feares, is worthy of Calamity.

sp.speaker: POM.
sp.l: Is not my Lord here?

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: Sir, he will be straight.Dio. ibid.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: What newes Fulcinius Trio?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Good, good tidings.
But, keepe it to your selfe. My Lord Seianus
Is to receiue this day, in open Senate,
The Tribuniciall dignity.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: Is't true?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: No words; not to your thought: but Sir beleeue it.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: What saies the Consul?

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: (Speake it not againe,)
He tells me, that to day my Lord Seianus—

sp.speaker: (TRI.
sp.l: I must entreat you Cotta, on your honor
Not to reueale it.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: On my life, Sir)

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: Say.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: Is to receiue the Tribuniciall power;
But, as you are an honorable man,
Let me coniure you, not to vtter it:
For it is trusted to me, with that bond.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: I am Harpocrates.

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: Can you assure it?

sp.speaker: POM.
sp.l: The Consul told it me, but keepe it close.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.l: Lord Latiaris, what's the newes?

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: Ile tell you,
But you must sweare to keepe it secret.—

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: I knew the Fates had on their distaffe left
More of our thread, then so.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: Hayle great Seianus.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Haile the Dio. lib. Hist. Rom. 58. pag. 718 most honor'd,

sp.speaker: CO.
sp.l: Happy,

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: High Seianus.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Do you bring Prodigies too?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: May all Presage
Turne to those faire effects, whereof we bring
Your Lordship newes.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: May't please my Lord withdraw.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Yes. I will speake with you, anone.

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: My Lord
What is your pleasure for the Tribunes?

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Why,
Let 'hem be thank't, and sent away.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.l: My Lord—

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: Wilt please your Lo: to command me—

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: No.
You' are troblesome.

sp.speaker: MI.
sp.l: The Dio. Hist. Rom. lib. 58. pag. 715. mood is chāg'd.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Not speak?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Nor looke?

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: I. "He is wise, wil make him friendes
"Of such, who neuer loue, but for their Endes.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: I, goe, make hast; Take heede you be not last
To tender yourAVE matutina vox salutanti propria, apud Romanos. Vid. Brifs. de for. lib. 8. ALL HAYLE, in the wide hall
Of huge Seianus: Runne, a Lictors pace;
Stay not to put your Roabes on; But, away,
With the pale troubled ensignes of great Friendship
Stamp't i'your face. Now, Marcus Lepidus,
You still beleeue your former Augurie?
Seianus must goe downeward? You perceiue
His wane approching fast?

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: Beleeue me, Lucius,
I wonder at this Rising!

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: I, and that we
Must giue our suffrage to it? You will say
It is to make his fall more steepe, and greiuous?
It may be so. But thinke it, they that can
With idle wishes 'ssay to bring back time;De Sanquinio. vid. 12. Ann. lib. 6.
"In cases desperate, all Hope is Crime.
See, see! what troupes of his officious Friendes
Flock to salute my LORD!Et de Haterio. ibid. and start before
My great, proud LORD, to get a LORD-like nod!

Attend MY LORD vnto the Senate-house! Ex Liburnia, magnae, & procerae staturae mittebantur, qui erant Rom. Lecticarij. Test. Iuuen. Sai 3. vers. 240.—turbâ cedente vehetur Diues, & ingenti curret super ora Liburno.
Bring back MY LORD! like seruile Huishers, make
Way for MY LORD! proclaime his Idoll LORD-ship,
More then ten Criers, or sixe noyse of Trumpetts!
Make leggs, kisse hands, and take a scatterd haire
From my LORDS excellent shoulder. See, Sanquinius!
With his slow belly, and his dropsy! Looke,
What toyling haste he makes lyet, here's another,
Retarded with the Goute, will be afore him!
Get thee Liburnian Porters, thou grosse Foole,
To beare thy'obsequious fatnesse, like thy Peeres.
They' are mett. The Goute returnes, and his great Carriage.

sp.speaker: LIC.
sp.l: Giue way, make place; Roome for the Consul.

sp.speaker: SA.
sp.l: HAYLE,
HAYLE great Seianus.

sp.speaker: HAT.
sp.l: HAYLE my honor'd Lord.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: We shall be markt anone for our not HAYLE.Dio. ibid.

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: That is all ready done.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: It is a note
Of vpstart Greatnesse, to obserue, and watch
For these poore trifles, which the noble mind
Neglects, and scornes.

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: I, and they thinke themselues
Deepely dishonor'd, where they are omitted,
As if they wereDio. ibid. necessityes, that helpt
To the perfection of their Dignities:
And hate the men, that but refraine'hem.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: ô
There is a farder cause of hate. Their breasts
Are guilty, that we know their obscure springs,
And base beginnings: Thence the anger growes. On. Follow.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: When all are entred,Dio pag. 718. shut the Temple doores;
And bring your Guardes vp to the Gate.

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: If you shal heare Commotion in the Senate,
Present your selfe: and charge on any man
Shall offer to come forth.

sp.speaker: LAC.
sp.l: I am instructed.

div.stage: THE SENATE. PRAECONES. LICTORES. REGVLVS. SEIANVS. TRIO. HATERIVS. SANQVINIVS. COTTA. POMPONIVS. LATIARIS. LEPIDVS. ARRVNTIVS.

sp.speaker: HAT.
sp.l: How well his Lordship lookes to day!

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: As if
He had beene borne, or made for this howers state.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: Your fellow Consul's come about, me thinkes?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I, hee'is wise.

sp.speaker: SAN.
sp.l: Seianus trusts him well.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Seianus is a noble, Ʋid. acclamation. Senat. Dio. pag. 719. bounteous Lord.

sp.speaker: HAT.
sp.l: Hee is so, and most valiant.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: And most wise.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.l: Hee's euery thing.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: Worthy of all, and more
Then bounty can bestow.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: This Dignity
Wil make him worthy.

sp.speaker: POM.
sp.l: Aboue Caesar.

sp.speaker: SAN.
sp.l: Tut,
Caesar is but theDio. Hist. Rom. lib. 58. 715. Rector of an I'sle,
Hee of the Empire.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Now he will haue power
More to reward, then euer.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: Let vs looke
We beDio. pag. 719. not slack in giuing him our voyces.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: SAN.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: The readyer we seeme
To propagate his Honors, will more bind
His thought to ours.

sp.speaker: HAT.
sp.l: I thinke right, with your Lordship.
It is the way to haue vs hold our Places.

sp.speaker: SAN.
sp.l: I, and get more.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: More Office, and more Titles.Dio. ibid.

sp.speaker: POM.
sp.l: I will not loose the part, I hope to share
In these his Fortunes, for my Patrimony.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: See how Arruntius sits, and Lepidus.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Let'hem alone, they will be markt anone.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.l: Ile doe, with others.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.l: So will I.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.l: And I.
Men grow not in the State, but as they are planted
Warme in his fauors.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: Noble Seianus.

sp.speaker: HAT.
sp.l: Honor'd Seianus.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: Worthy and great Seianus.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: Gods! how the Spunges open, and take in!
And shut againe! Looke, looke! Is not he blest
That gets a seate in eye-reach of him? more,
That comes in eare, or tongue-reach? O but most,
Can claw his subtle elbow, or with a buzze
Flie blow his eares.

sp.speaker: PRAET.
sp.l: Proclaime the Senates peace;
And giue last summons by the Edict.

sp.speaker: PRAE.
sp.l: Silence.
In name of CAESAR, and the SENATE. SILENCE.

div.stage: Vid. Brissonium: de formul. lib. 2. Et Lipsium Sat. Menip.MEMMIVS REGVLVS. AND. FVLCINIVS. TRIO. CONSVL'S. THESE. PRESENT. KALENDES. OF. IVNE. VVITH. THE. FIRST. LIGHT. SHALL. HOLD. A. SENATE. IN. THE. TEMPLE. OF. Palatinus, à monte Palatino, dictus. APOLLO. PALATINE. ALL. THAT. ARE. FATHERS. AND. ARE. REGISTRED. FATHERS. THAT. HAVE. RIGHT. OF. ENTRING. THE. SENATE. VVE. VVARNE. OR. COMMAVND. YOV. BE. FREQVENTLY. PRESENT. TAKE. KNOVVLEDGE. THE. BVSINESSE. IS. THE. COMMON. VVEALTHES. VVHOSOEVER. IS. ABSENT. HIS. FINE. OR. MVLCT. VVILL. BE. TAKEN. HIS. EXCVSE. VVILL. NOT. BE. TAKEN.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Note, who are absent, and record their names.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: Solemnis praefatio Consulum in relationibus. Dio. pag. 718. FATHERS CONSCRIPT. MAY VVHAT I AM TO VTTER,
TVRNE GOOD AND HAPPY FOR THE COMMON VVEALTH.
And thou APOLLO, in whose holy House
We here are met, Inspire vs all, with truth,
And liberty of Censure to our thought.
The Maiestie of great Tiberius Caesar
Propounds to this graue Senate, the bestowing
Vpon the man he lones, honour'd Seianus,
Here are his Letters, signed with his signet:
Alia formula solemnis. vid. Briss. lib. 2. WHAT PLEASETH NOVV THE FATHERS TO BE DONE?

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.l: Read, read 'hem, open, publiquely, Read 'hem.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: Caesar hath honour'd his owne greatnesse much,
In thinking of this Act.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: It was a thought
Happy, and worthy Caesar.

sp.speaker: LAT.
sp.l: And the Lord,
As worthy it, on whom it is directed.

sp.speaker: HAT.
sp.l: Most worthy.

sp.speaker: SAN.
sp.l: Rome did neuer boast the vertue
That could giue Enuie bounds, but his: Seianus.—

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.l: Honor'd, and noble.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.l: Good, and great Seianus.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: O most tame slauery, and fierce Flattery!

sp.speaker: PRAE.
sp.p: Silence.
sp.stage: TIBERIVS CAESAR TO THE SENATE GREETING.
sp.p:
Solenne exordium Epistolar. apud Romanos. Cons. Briss. de formul. lib. 8. IF. YOV. CONSCRIPT. FATHERS. VVITH. YOVR. CHILDREN. BE. IN. HEALTH. IT. IS. ABOVNDANTLY. VVELL. VVE. VVITH. OVR. FRIENDS. HERE. ARE. SO. The care of the Common-wealth, howsoeuer we are remou'd in person, cannot bee absent to our thought; although, oftentimes, euen to Princes most present, the truth of their owne affaires is hid: then which, nothing falls out more miserable to a State, or makes the art of gouerning more difficult. But since it hath beene our easefull happinesse to enioy both the aydes, and industrie of so vigilant a Senate, wee professe to haue beene the more indulgent to our pleasures, not as beeing carelesse of our office, but rather secure of the necessity. Neither doe these common Rumors of many, and infamous Libels published against our retirement, at all afflict vs; beeing borne more out of mens ignorance, then their malice: and will, neglected, finde their owne graue quickly, whereas too sensiblie acknowledg'd, it would make their obloquie ours. Nor doe wee desire their Authors (though found) bee censur'd,
Ʋid. Sue. Tib. cap. 28. since in a free State (as ours) all men ought to enioy both their mindes, and tongues free.

sp.speaker: (ARR.
sp.p: The Lapwing, the Lapwing.)

Yet in things: which shall worthily, and more neare concerne the Maiesty of a Prince, we shall feare to bee so vnnaturally cruell to our owne fame, as to neglect them. True it is, CONSCRIPT FATHERS, that we haue raised Seianus, from obscure, and almost vnknowne Gentry,

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.p: How! how!

p.hi: to the highest, and most conspicuous point of greatnesse, and (wee hope) deseruingly; yet not without daunger: it beeing a most bolde hazard in that Sou'raigne, who, by his particular loue to one, dar •• aduenture the hatred of all his other subiects.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.p: This Touches, the blood turnes.
But we affie in your Loues, and vnderstandings, and do no way suspect the merit of our Seianus to make our fauours offensiue to any.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.p: O, good, good.

Though we could haue wishd his Zeale had runne a calmer course against Agrippina, and our Nephues, howsoeuer the opennesse of their actions, declared them delinquents; and, that he would haue remembred, no Innocence is so safe, but it reioyceth to stand in the sight of Mercie: The vse of which in vs, he hath so quite taken away, toward them, by his loyall fury, as now our Clemencie would be • thought but wearied Cruelty, if wee should offer to excercise it.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.p: I thanke him, there I look'd for't. A good Foxel

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.p: 'This 'strange.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.p: I shall anone beleeue your Vultures, Marcus.

p.hi: Your wisdomes, CONSCRIPT FATHERS, are able to examine, and censure these suggestions: but, were they left to our absoluing voice, we durst pronounce them, as we thinke them, most malicious.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.p: O he has restor'd all, List.

Yet, are they offerd to be auerr'd, and on the liues of the Informers: What we should say, or rather what we should not say, Lords of the Senate, if this be true, our Gods, and Goddesses confound vs if wee know! Onely, we must thinke we haue plac'd our benefits ill; and conclude, that in our choise, either wee were wanting to the Gods, or the Gods to vs.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.p:
The place growes hot, they shift. VVee haue not bene couetous, HONORABLE FATHERS, to change; neither
is it now, any new Lust that alters our affection, or old Loathing, but those needfull Iealousies of state, that warne wiser Princes, howrely, to prouide their safty; and do teach them how learned a thing it is to beware of the humblest Enemie: much more of those great ones, whom their owne emploid fauours haue made fit for their feares.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.p: Sit farder.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Lett's remooue—

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.p: Gods! how the leaues drop off, this little winde!

p.hi: we therefore desire that the Offices he holds, be first seized by the Senate; and himselfe suspended from all exercise of place, or power—

sp.speaker: SE.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: SA.
sp.p: By your leaue.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: Come Porcpisce (wher's Haterius?
Dio. Hist. Rom. lib. 58 pag. 719. His Gout keepes him most miserably constant.)
Your dauncing shewes a tempest.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Read no more.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: Lords of the Senate, hold your seates; read on.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: These Letters they are forg'd.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: a guard, Sit still.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: Here's change.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: Bid silence, and read forward.

sp.speaker: PRAE.
sp.p:
Silence, — and himselfe suspended from all excercise of place, or power, (but till due and mature tryall bee made of his innocencie, which yet we can faintly apprehend the necessity, to doubt.) If CONSCRIPT FATHERS, to your more searching wisdomes, there shal appeare farther cause (or of farder proceeding, eyther to seyzure of Lands, Goods, or more—) It is not our power that shall limite your authoritie, or our fauour, that must corrupt your iustice; either were dishonourable in you, and both vncharitable to our selfe. Dio. ibid.
We would willingly be present with your Counsailes in this businesse, but the daunger of so potent a faction (if it should prooue so) forbiddes our attempt: except one of the Consuls would be intreated for our safety to vndertake the guard of vs home, then wee should most readily aduenture. In the meane time, it shall not bee fit for vs to importune so iudicious a Senate, who knowe howe much they hurt the innocent, that spare the guilty, and howe gratefull a sacrifice, to the Gods, is the life of an ingratefull person. We reflect not in this on Seianus (notwithstanding if you keepe an eye vpon him—And there is Latiaris a Senatour, and Pinnarius Natta, two of his most trusted Ministers, and so profest, whom we desire not to haue apprênded, but as the necessity of the cause exacts it.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: A guard on Latiaris.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: O, the Spie!
The reuerend Spie is caught, who pitties him?
Reward sir for your seruice; now you ha'done
Your property, you see what vse is made?
Hang vp the Instrument.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Giue leaue.

sp.speaker: LACO.
sp.l: Stand, stand,
He comes vpon his death, that doth aduance
An inch toward my point.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Haue we no friend here?

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: Hush't. Where now are all the HAYLES, and acclamations?

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: Haile, to the Consuls, and this noble Senate. Dio. ibid.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Is Macro here? O, thou art lost, Seianus.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: Sit still, and vnaffrighted, Reuerend Fathers.
Macro, by Caesars Grace, the new-made Pronost,
And now possest of the Praetorian bandes,
(An honour late belongd to that proud man)
Biddes you, be safe: and to your constant doome
Of his deseruings, offers you the surety
Of all the Souldiers, Tribunes, and Centurions
Receiu'd in our command.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: Stand forth, Seianus.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Am I call'd?

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: I, thou,
Thou insolent monster, art bid stand.

sp.speaker: SEI.
sp.l: Why, Macro,
It hath bene otherwise, betweene you, and I?
This Court, that knowes vs both, hath seene a difference,
And can (if it be pleasd to speake) confirme
Whose insolence is most.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: Come downe, Typhan • ,
If mine be most, loe thus I make it more;
Kick vp thy heeles in ayre, teare off thy roabe,
Play with thy beard, and nostrils: Thus 'tis fit
(And no man take compassion of thy state)
To vse th'ingratefull viper, tread his braines
Into the earth.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: For beare.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: If I could loose
All my humanity now, 'twere well to torture
So meriting a Traytor. Wherefore, Fathers,
Sit you amaz'd, and silent? and not censure
This wretch, who in the howre he first rebeld
'Gainst Caesars bounty, did condemne himselfe?
P'hlegra, the field, where all the Sonnes of Earth
Muster'd against the Gods, did nere acknowledge
So proud, and huge a monster.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: take him hence.
And all the Gods guard Caesar.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Take him hence.

sp.speaker: HAT.
sp.l: Hence.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: To the dungeō with him.

sp.speaker: SAN.
sp.l: He deserues it.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.l: Crowne all our dores with Bayes.

sp.speaker: SAN.
sp.l: And let an Oxe
With gilded hornes, and Gyrlonds, straight be led
Vnto the Capitoll:

sp.speaker: HAT.
sp.l: And sacrific'd
Ieg. Iuuen. S • tyr. 10.To Ioue, for Caesars safety.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: All our Gods
Be present still to Caesar.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.l: All guard him.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l: Forth, thou Prodigie of men.

sp.speaker: COT.
sp.l: Let all the traitors Titles be defac'd.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: His Images, and Statues be puld downe.

sp.speaker: HAT.
sp.l: His Chariot wheeles be broken.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: And the Legs
Of the poore Horses, that deserued naught,
Let them be broken too.

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: O violent change,
And whirle of mens affections!

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: Like, as both
Their bulkes and soules were bound on Fortunes wheele,
And must act onely with her motion.

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: Who would depend vpon the popular ayre,
Or voice of men, that haue to day beheld
(That which if all the Gods had fore-declar'd,
Would not haue bene beleeu'd) SEIANVS fall?
He, that this morne rose proudly, as the Sunne;
And, breaking through a mist of Clients breath,
Came on as gaz'd at, and admir'd, as he
When superstitious Moores salute his light!
That had our seruile Nobles waiting him
As common-Groomes; and hanging on his looke,
No lesse then humane Life on Desteny!
That had mens knees as frequent, as the Gods;
And Sacrifices, more, then Rome had Altars:
Dio. lib. 58. pag. 719. 720. &c. And this man fall! Fall? I, without a looke,
That durst appeare his friend; or lend so much
Of vaine reliefe, to his chang'd state, as pitty!

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: They, that before like Gnats plaid in his Beames,
And throng'd to circumscribe him, now not seene!
Nor deigne to hold a common seate with him!
Others, that waited him vnto the Senate,
Now, inhumanely rauish him to prison!
Whom (but this morne) they follow'd as their Lord,
Guard through the streetes, bound like a fugitiue!
In stead of wreaths, giue fetters; stroakes for stoopes:
Blind shame for Honors; and black taunts for Titles!
Who would trust slippery Chance?

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: They, that would make
Themselues her spoile; and foolishly forget,
When she doth flatter, that she comes to prey:
"Fortune, thou hadst no Deity, if men
"Had wisdome: we haue placed thee so high,
"By fond beleefe in thy felicity.

div.stage: SHOVTE VVITHIN. The Gods guard Caesar. All the Gods guard Caesar.

sp.speaker: MAC.
sp.l:
Now great Seianus, you that aw'd the State,
Vid. Dion. Hist. Rom. lib. 58. pag. 720. 721. 722. 723.
And sought to bring the Nobles to your whip.
That would be Caesars Tutor, and dispose
Of Dignities, and Offices, that had
The publique head still bare to your dissignes,
And made the generall voyce to Eccho yours,
That look'd for Salutations, twelue score off,
And would haue Pyramid's, yea Temples rear'd
To your huge Greatnesse: Now, you lie as flat,
As was your pride aduanc'd.

sp.speaker: REG.
sp.l: Thankes to the Gods.

sp.speaker: SEN.
sp.l: And praise to Macro, that hath saued Rome.
Liberty, liberty, liberty. Lead on,
And praise to Macro, that hath saued Rome.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: I prophesie, out of this Senates flattery,
That this new fellow, Macro, will become
A greater Prodigie in Rome, then he
That now is falne.

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: ô you, whose mindes are good,
And haue not forc'd all mankind, from your brests;
That yet haue so much stock of vertue left,
To pitty guilty states, when they are wretched:
Lend your soft eares to heare, and eyes to weepe
Deedes done by men, beyond the Acts of Furies.
The eager Multitude, who neuer yet
Knew why to loue, or hate, but only pleas'd
T'expresse their rage of power, no sooner heard
The murmure of Seianus in decline,
But with that speed, and heate of appetite,
With which they greedily deuoure the way
To some great Sports, or a new Theatre;
They fill'd the Capitoll, and Pompei's Circke:
Where, like so many Mastiues, biting stones,
As if his Statues now were sensitiue
Of their wild fury, first they teare them downe:
Then fastning ropes, drag them along the streetes,
Vid. Iuuen. Sat. 10.Crying in scorne, this, this was that rich head
Was crown'd with Gyrlonds, and with Odours, This
That was in Rome so reuerenced. Now
The Furnace, and the Bellowes shall to worke
The great Seianus crack, and peice, by peice,
Drop i'the Founders pit.

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: O popular Rage!

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: Dio. Rom. Hist. lib. 58. pag. 720. The whilst, the Senate, at the Temple of Concord,
Make haste to meete againe, and thronging cry,
Let vs condemne him, tread him downe in water,
While he doth lie vpon the banke; Away:
Where some, more tardy, crie vnto their bearers,
He will be censur'd êre we come, runne Knaues,
And vse that furious diligence, for feare
Their Bond-men should informe against their slacknesse,
And bring their quaking flesh vnto the hooke:
The Rout, they follow with confused voyce
Crying, they 'are glad, say they could nere abide him;
Enquire, what Man he was? what kind of Face?
What Beard he had? what Nose? what Lips? protest▪
They euer did presage h'would come to this:
They neuer thought him wise, nor valiant: Aske
After his Garments, when he dyes? what death?
And not a Beast of all the Heard demands
What was his Crime? or who were his Accusers?
Vnder what proofe, or testimony, he fell?
There came (saies one) a huge, long, worded Letter
From Capraeae against him. Did there so?
O, they are satisfied, no more.

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: Alasse!
They follow Fortune, and hate men condemn'd,Iuue. Sat. 10.
Guilty, or not.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: But had Seianus thriu'd
In his dissigne, and prosperously opprest
The old Tiberius, then, in that same minute
These very Raskalls, that now rage like Furies,
Would haue proclaim'd Seianus Emperour.

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: But what hath follow'd?

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: Sentence, by the Senate; Dio. ibid.

To loose his head: which was no sooner off,
Senec. lib. de Tranq. Anim. cap. 11.
Quo die illum Senatus deduxerat, Populus in frusta diuisit, &c.
But that, and th'vnfortunate trunke were seizd
By the rude multitude; who not content
With what the forward Iustice of the State
Officiously had done, with violent rage
Haue rent it limbe, from limbe. A thousand heads,
A thousand hands, ten thousand tongues, and voices
Employd at once in seuerall actes of malice.
Old Men not staid with Age, Virgins with shame,
Late Wiues with losse of Husbands, Mothers of Children,
Loosing all griefe in ioy of his sad fall,
Runne quite transported with their cruelty:
These mounting at his head, these at his face,
These digging out his eyes, those with his braine,
Sprinkling themselues, their houses, and their friends:
Others are met, haue rauish'd thence an arme,
And deale small pieces of the flesh for Fauors;
These with a thigh; this hath cut off his hands;
And this his feete; these fingers, and these toes;
That hath his liuer; he his heart; there wants
Nothing but roome for wrath, and place for hatred.
What cannot oft be done, is now ôre done.
The whole, and All of what was great Seianus,
And next to Caesar did possesse the world,
Now torne, and scatterd, as he needs no graue,
Each little dust couers a little part:
So lies he no where, and yet often buried.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: More of Seianus?

sp.speaker: NVN.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: LEP
sp.l: What can be added?
We know him dead.

sp.speaker: NVN.
sp.l: Then there begin your pitty,
There is inough behin'd, to melt eu'n Rome,
And Caesar into teares: (though neuer Slaue
Could yet so highly 'offend, but Tyranny
In torturing him would make him worth lamenting.)
A sonne, and daughter to the dead Seianus,
(Of whomVid Senec. lib. de Tranq. Ani. cap. xi. there is not now so much remaining
As would giue fastning to the Hang-mans hooke)
Haue they drawne forth for farder sacrifice;
Whose tendernesse of knowledge, vnripe yeares,
And childish silly Innocence was such,
As scarse would lend them feeling of their danger:
TheTac. Ann. lib. 5. pa. 99. Et Dion. lib. 58. pag. 720. Girle so simple, as she often askt,

l.hi: Where they would lead her? for what cause they dragd her?

sp.l: Cry'd, She would doe no more. That she could take
Warning with beating. And because our Lawes
Admit no virginLex enim non tam virginitati ignotum cautumque voluit quā aeta • i. Cons. Lips. Comment. Tac. immature to dye,
The wittely, and strangly-cruell Macro
Deliuer'd her to be deflowr'd, and spoild,
By the rude lust of the licentious Hang-man,
Then, to be strangled with her harmelesse brother.

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: ô Act, most worthy Hell, and lasting night,
To hide it from the world!

sp.speaker: NVN.
sp.l: Their bodies throwne
Into the Gemonies, (I know not how
Or by what accident returnd) the Mother,

Th'expulsedDio. ibid.
Apicata, finds them there;
Whom when she saw lie spread on theScalae Gemoniae in quas erant protecta damnator. Corpora. Degrees,
After a world of Furie on her selfe,
Tearing her haire, defacing of her face,
Beating her brests, and wombe, kneeling amaz'd,
Crying to heauen, then to them; at last,
Her drowned voyce gate vp aboue her woes:
And with such black, and bitter execrations,
(As might affright the Gods, and force the Sunne
Runne backward to the East, nay, make the old
Deformed Chaos rise againe t'ore-whelme
Them, vs, and all the world) she fills the ayre;
Vpbraids the Heauens with their partiall doomes,
Defies their tyrannous powers, and demaunds
What she, and those poore Innocents haue transgress'd,
That they must suffer such a share in vengeance, Dio. Hist. Rom. lib. 58. pag. 720.
Whilst Liuia, Lygdus, and Eudemus liue,
Who, (as she say's, and firmely vowes, to proue it
To Caesar, and the Senate) poyson'd Drusus?

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: Confederats with her husband?

sp.speaker: NVN.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: Strange Act!

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: And strangly opend: what say's now my Monster,
The Multitude? They reele now? do they not?

sp.speaker: NVN.
sp.l: Their Gall is gone, and now they gin to weepe
The mischiefe they haue done.

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: I thanke 'hem, Rogues!

sp.speaker: NVN.
sp.l: Part are so stupide, or so flexible,
As they beleeue him innocent; All grieue:
And some, whose hands yet reeke with his warme blood,
And gripe the part which they did teare of him,
Wish him collected, and created new.

sp.speaker: LEP.
sp.l: How Fortune plies her sports, when she begins
To practise 'hem! pursues, continues, addes!
Confounds, with varying her empassion'd moodes!

sp.speaker: ARR.
sp.l: Dost thou hope Fortune to redeeme thy crimes,
To make amends, for thy ill placed fauours
With these strange punishments? Forbeare, you Things,
That stand vpon the Pinnacles of State,
To boast your slippery height; when you do fall,
You pash your selues in peices, nêre to rise,
And he that lends you pitty, is not wise.

sp.speaker: TER.
sp.l: Let this example mooue th'insolent man,
Not to grow proud, and carelesse of the Gods:
"It is an odious wisdome, to blaspheme,
"Much more to slighten, or deny their powers.
For whom the Morning saw so great, and high,
Thus low, and little, 'fore the 'Euen doth lye.
